comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: A wonderful image from a fantastic set. Probably my favourite. Thank you for sharing these. Don't wish to sound critical, but is it me or has this been digitised slightly off-square? -- Seen in a discussion of the group "Flickr Commons" (?)

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I had thought from a search of this address on Google Maps / Streetview that it looked like the whole of this side of the street had been redeveloped now, but I had a browse around up and down the street and next to the new block stumbled across this exact same building, as it is today. It's now an antique shop.

comment.author: 30057424@N07
comment._content: more than 100 years old... precious document !

comment.author: 25334189@N07
comment._content:
Many of the Atget prints in our collection show angled edges that make the images appear as if they were digitized somewhat off center. This trimming was either done by Atget or someone else before they came into the collection at GEH.  I asked around this morning and it is not common to see albumen prints with these angled edges, however it is common to most of the Atget prints in our collection.  I sent out an email to a colleague in Paris who has the definitive Atget collection and asked if their prints show the same edges.  I will share the information when I get a response.  
Thanks for the question!

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Jessica, fascinating response, and it explains why it looks that way. Look forward to hearing more from Paris. Just as an aside, one of my colleagues who is French may be in Rouen this weekend and he was thinking of going to see this building. I also emailed the owner of the art gallery that can now be found there, but have had no response as yet.

comment.author: 8602013@N02
comment._content: first time i've seen this one - love the composition here

comment.author: 38712296@N07
comment._content: The building does not exist anymore : it was is located in parts of Rouen which suffered heavy bombings during WWII. The "Rue Molière" still exists. Someone sold a postcard on EBay which is the same place but with a different angle. It is titled "Marchande des 4 saisons" Carte postale Marchande des 4 saisons sur EBay

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: That postcard is a great find. I note your point about the building being destroyed in WWII, but isn't it the building that is now an art gallery, as shown on Google Maps? You have given me doubts now and maybe it is just a neighbouring building in the same style?

comment.author: 38712296@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture/] oops ! Sorry, I was too quick on this one… You’re right ! It’s still here !

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I wonder if the gallery owner knows about this photograph? I did try to email him, but got no reply.
